SIRS!

It has been a while since I've posted, and I admit I 
haven't been reading a lot about recent 
developments, *but*...

(and I'll try to be interesting while I discuss 
ideas, I promise!).

9/15/01 8:28:59 PM, dph_of_rules@... wrote:

>What kind of expectations are there about 
tournament scenarios?  Is 
>there anything that the tournament scenarios should 
NOT like? [Members 
> of the tournament group can participate in this, 
but need to keep 
>tournament group secrets SECRET.]

I expect the scenarios to be quality, and I expect 
the builders to exercise some caution when 
considering balance.  Just because your scenario 
doesn't end up yielding the most in silver and gold 
doesn't mean it wasn't the most enjoyable to play.

I'm also not a big fan of your standard mazes... 
something about walking through piles upon piles of 
the same two textures just doesn't appeal to me.

What I'd like to see the builders do is collaborate 
on a story that makes sense, and have each scene - 
no matter how small - concentrate on pieces of this 
story.  One of the coolest parts about playing 
Gladiator, to me, is reading the scenario 
introductions.  It irks me when these introductions 
are poorly written, non-existent or completely 
uninteresting and uninformative.

>Also, considering the tournament is only 20 
scenarios long, what type 
>of teams are you considering?  Remember: every team 
has to have at 
>least 4 members.

If 20 scenarios is an 'only,' consider the 
following:  a team of five people will require each 
member to pump out FOUR quality scenarios.  I don't 
know about you guys, but it takes me a few tries to 
get even *one* map as entertaining as those in the 
original gladiator package.

I opt for a smaller number of scenarios (read: 5-10) 
because builders will be able to concentrate on 
quality and a consistent, well-written storyline.  
There will also be less variability in score if 
there are fewer scenarios; cheaters won't have as 
much room.  Of course, if people are going to cheat, 
you can't stop them.  It's easy to cheat only a 
little bit, or 'bend' the rules by harvesting slimes 
or badguy generators so you can make a scenario last 
forever.

>The team I am considering is 2 clerics and 1 fire 
elemental.  I 
>haven't quite figured out who my 4th team member 
will be, but it 
>wouldn't be a thief, a mage, a skeleton, or a 
ghost.

If this tournament has 20 scenarios in it, my team 
will probably have two clerics, a druid, and yeah, a 
fire elemental - just because they pack so much 
punch for a decent price.  Why the druid?  The trees 
are pretty powerful if you use them as an attack in 
the early levels, and a great defense mechanism - if 
you can keep your teammates behind the border!
